awd_titl_txt: REU Site:  Advancing Undergraduate Research Among Minorities in Plant Biology Enrolled in an Urban Community College
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to Borough of Manhattan Community College (BMCC) located in New York, NY, will support the training of eight students for eight weeks during each of the summers of 2019-2021. Student research focuses on bioactivity of natural products at different biological levels of organization (e.g., the potential antioxidant capacity of natural plant products used in different cultural groups, the effects of natural extracts on microorganisms in fresh water and marine environments with changing salinity, in regulating genes involved in differentiation of cells, and in potential protective effects on growth of mammalian cells).  Students will receive training in all aspects of the scientific method including biostatistics, and workshops in professional development including scientific communication (oral presentations, scientific writing), lab safety, ethics/responsible conduct of research and STEM careers. Field trips to  internationally recognized botanical gardens,  an agricultural experiment station and an herb farm will introduce students to sources of many natural extracts, with emphasis on research in plant sciences and networking opportunities. The program culminates with each student preparing a research paper and giving an oral presentation on their individual research.
   It is anticipated that a total of 24 students primarily from underrepresented groups from community colleges with limited research opportunities will be trained in the program. Students will learn how to conduct research, develop professional skills, and may present their work at scientific conferences. With community colleges accounting for more than half of all undergraduate enrollments, the BMCC REU program may serve as a national model for other two-year institutions involved in STEM research which seek to encourage and facilitate transfer of STEM majors to four-year institutions.
  A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU Site programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available by visiting https://www.bmcc.cuny.edu/gra/page.jsp?pid=1080&n=REU, or by contacting the PI Adolfina Koroch (akoroch@bmcc.cuny.edu) or the Co-PI Alexander Gosslau (agosslau@bmcc.cuny.edu).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This REU Site award to Borough of Manhattan Community College (BMCC), located in New York, NY, supported the training of 24 students for eight weeks during summers of 2019-2022. Student research focused on bioactivity of natural products at different biological levels of organization. Students received training in all aspects of the scientific method including biostatistics, and workshops in professional development including scientific communication (oral presentations, scientific writing), lab safety, ethics/responsible conduct of research, and STEM careers. Field trips were organized to internationally recognized botanical gardens, and to virtual conferences of the American Council for Medicinally Active Plants (ACMAP) annual meetings in 2021 and 2022 where there was emphasis on research in plant sciences and networking opportunities. The program culminated with each student preparing a research paper and giving an oral presentation on their individual research.

 Participants became part of the community by participating in weekly meetings and workshops, and by interacting with other researchers such as previous REU participants and graduate students with diverse professional experience. Students experienced life at the laboratory while working collaboratively with other students and faculty. Students further discovered new career paths with the help of faculty who encouraged them to pursue graduate degrees in STEM areas.

 The Program succeeded in preparing undergraduates for professions in science. Formal assessments conducted during the summers indicated that students gained skills in formulating hypotheses, designing experiments, data collection, and drawing conclusions. Additional skills were gained in scientific communication, including oral presentations and writing scientific papers. Participants also gained technical skills in the laboratory that reflected the needs of their individual projects. Among the research contributions, 9 REU participants participated and presented a poster of their research at ACMAP and ASCB conferences.  In addition, 7 program participants are co-authors on three peer-reviewed literature publications, and on two additional manuscripts that are in various stages of preparation.

 Our program had an emphasis on impacting students early in their college careers; 50% of the REU students had finished two years of college. All 12 community college students transferred to four-year schools to continue their education. Of the 24 students in the program, 13 are currently in a four-year school, 2 are working in a STEM field, 2 are in a masters programs, and 4 are applying to graduate school.

 With community colleges accounting for more than half of all undergraduate enrollments, the BMCC REU program may serve as a national model for other two-year institutions involved in STEM research that seek to encourage and facilitate transfer of STEM majors to four-year institutions.
